content.content: Eumenes:  The current jack of all trades master of none isnt working   I’m afraid I can’t agree with this statement. Is the system perfect? No. However, we have realized significant benefits since the introduction of the delegation system. The presence of identifiable actors who wield voting power is IMO a net gain to the protocol. There is a reason that other protocols are modelling their delegation systems on the MakerDAO delegation system (see Interest Protocol whitepaper for an example). Because Recognized Delegates are incentivized to provide the rationale for their voting decisions, we get actionable feedback on failed proposals. Before the delegates, the author of a failed proposal would have no way of knowing why their proposal had failed or how to amend it to make it viable at the on-chain stage. This benefit applies equally to community members and CUs - see discussions around CU budgets. Similarly, the ability to pass Executive Votes promptly is not to be under-estimated in terms of the security gains and ability to execute changes to the Maker Protocol at the technical layer. Before delegates, the community often had to resort to appealing on Twitter or other social media for votes to push Executives over the line. Regarding specialized delegates - all delegates are welcome to specialize if they choose. A delegate can create a platform that states they will only vote in RWF-related votes and executives and otherwise abstain. This would be perfectly valid; if MKR holders wanted this kind of delegate, they would be able to delegate to them. For compensation, “abstain” is a valid vote.

content.content: Eumenes:  it appears to incentivize the jack of all trades voting approach, no?   Delegates can abstain on votes where they feel they do not possess the necessary knowledge without penalty. Specialized delegates are an interesting concept - outside of delegates abstaining on votes, there isn’t really a good way to work things. Are you envisioning that an MKR holder could delegate to delegate A for votes on x, and to delegate B for votes on y? In practice, I suspect it would be very difficult to do this from a technical perspective - requiring rewriting the delegate contract and possibly the voting contract. The alternative would be to solve this at a social level, where delegates can team up (officially as a unified delegate group, or unofficially) so that delegate A could defer to Delegate B in votes where they feel they lack their counterpart’s expertise. This would require an overhaul of the compensation structure (which is something we’re interested in looking at) if we wanted delegates to formalise these relationships but this could also be done unofficially under the status quo system.

content.content: Patrick_J:  Delegates can abstain on votes where they feel they do not possess the necessary knowledge without penalty. Specialized delegates are an interesting concept - outside of delegates abstaining on votes, there isn’t really a good way to work things. Are you envisioning that an MKR holder could delegate to delegate A for votes on x, and to delegate B for votes on y? In practice, I suspect it would be very difficult to do this from a technical perspective - requiring rewriting the delegate contract and possibly the voting contract.   I think you are missing the thrust of what @Eumenes is getting at and what a number of Delegates have been highlighting as an issue, including myself. The problem is not strictly speaking lack of knowledge and being penalized. It’s about capacity and commensurate incentives sufficient to compensate for risk and opportunity cost. The community is getting by so far with a laissez faire approach to Delegated Governance where no one is really responsible for or accountable to the decentralized organization as a whole. Given MakerDAO’s product and service offerings, utilization of domain expertise in governance is a must which we can do while also maintaining an open, flexible realm of participation for a wide spectrum of backgrounds and intentions. Abstaining from voting for reasons other than a conflict of interest, doesn’t get the job done that needs doing. But it is the logical option for a single Delegate without a more specific mandate from the community that addresses the need for a composable executive function. A next iteration of Delegated governance probably would require some technical changes.

content.content: I’ve moved this to a new thread to prevent cluttering the previous one. Simply put, we do not have the technical capacity to overhaul the delegation system. PE is focussing on L2, teleport, compound D3M and other high-value projects. DUX is concentrating on gasless voting and a polling metadata overhaul, which will allow for much more granular voting options. So, any changes we make in the short term must work within the confines of the current system.     ACREinvest:  I think you are missing the thrust of what @Eumenes is getting at and what a number of Delegates have been highlighting as an issue, including myself. The problem is not strictly speaking lack of knowledge and being penalized. It’s about capacity and commensurate incentives sufficient to compensate for risk and opportunity cost.   I don’t think I have missed the thrust at all. I may disagree or agree with various points being raised, but the issue isn’t whether or not I agree but how we proceed as a DAO. What I am asking for is actionable feedback or suggestions on how things should be changed to fix the perceived problems. To take the example of specialized delegates, it’s easy to say “we need specialized delegates” but that lacks any detail that would be required to even consider an implementation plan. For example:  Who assesses whether someone is suitable to be considered specialized? How does the delegation process change to accommodate specialized delegates? Does an MKR holder pick from a selection of specialists in different areas? Can a delegate opt to exist outside the specialized delegate framework? How do we pay them? Can specialized delegates vote on issues outside their stated area of expertise?  If the idea is a board of directors model:  How are they nominated? How are they selected/elected? How are they removed? How long do they serve before needing re-election? Term limits? What explicit powers do they have?      ACREinvest:  Given MakerDAO’s product and service offerings, utilization of domain expertise in governance is a must which we can do while also maintaining an open, flexible realm of participation for a wide spectrum of backgrounds and intentions.   I generally agree with this. In my opinion, the best way to attract expertise is with an incentive structure. Regarding incentives, for what it’s worth, I am generally in favour of increased incentives and have been suggesting this internally. However, I still believe that any incentive structure should, at a minimum:  Scale with the amount of MKR delegated. Be weighted towards smaller delegates to encourage new delegates to come forward - although we could adjust the current weighting. Have some form of limit - although I think we could raise this significantly from the current one. Provide controls against abuse/sybil issues - participation and comms metrics do this at present.  I would be open to hearing any suggested changes to the compensation structure from you or any of the other @Recognized-Delegates. This could be a good topic for an issue discussion call so it can be discussed in real-time (@Davidutro @thomas.flitter).

content.content: @Patrick_J I’ve always envisioned this DAO helping scale delegate platforms that are proven and shown 100% commitment to MakerDAO and only MakerDAO. In simple words, funding an established delegate platform that is fully dedicated for the benefit of MakerDAO. And by scaling I’m referring to building a team that consist of hires that become knowledgeable of the Maker ecosystem and it’s products. These individuals are hired with a skill set related to necessary subject matters related to the Maker realm and help each delegate platform make an executive decision and participate in all voter committees, office hours, MIP6/67 presentations, Core Unit initiatives, etc. Similar to what these teams that are delegates (Gauntlet, GFX, etc.) are doing/juggling  for many platforms + ecosystems, except that these funded delegate platforms that I imagine are focusing on all things MakerDAO as an internal Team. All-in-all this is what I had envisioned since day 1, and I don’t know if this will ever come into fruition because there are many irons in the fire. But I truly believe Delegates-as-a-Team (DaaT) can be more productive for the benefit to all things MakerDAO.

content.content: Patrick_J:  Yes, this is something we’ve discussed internally recently and I’m sympathetic to the idea - essentially should comp at the top end be enough for a delegate to hire a team to work with/for them?   Last time I thought about this (1 2), the conclusion that seemed sound is that additional compensation should not depend on the amount of MKR delegated. If it does then this actually hinders MKR owners from expressing their views. That is, it should be possible to delegate 10k MKR to team A and 20k MKR to team B and give equal funding to both teams. Hence, I would suggest that Recognized Delegates develop a MIP40-like DAI budget that can be approved by MKR holders. This budget would be in addition to the usual MIP61 compensation and be scaled by the MIP61 Performance Modifier. The budget should justify why the work funded is not a DAO-wide common good that should be conducted by a core unit (such as Data Insights). That’s my proposal.

content.content: I’m not convinced by this idea.     psychonaut:  That is, it should be possible to delegate 10k MKR to team A and 20k MKR to team B and give equal funding to both teams.   I’m not sure this is a necessary outcome we need to design for, given the confounding variables of other delegators etc. But, if we wanted this system we could remove the quadratic from the delegate compensation formula which would also simplify things to a degree rather than adding extra complexity. It’s fairly important that delegate rewards scale with delegated MKR as the net security benefit they provide the protocol also scales with this metric. I don’t like the idea of breaking this - one could argue the current system is also breaking this for those above 10,000 MKR, which is why I think we should start to look at moving out of the bootstrapping phase. Some follow-up questions about this to consider:  How much do you think is a reasonable number? Are all delegates entitled to the same flat amount if they meet the metric requirements?  If No - why not build it into other compensation structures instead of making a new one? If Yes - this produces a vector for exploitation.   Who should control the budget stream? (The answer is not GovAlpha).  To add, there is nothing stopping a delegate from proposing a budget to fund operational expenses as things stand if they wish. They are welcome to make that proposal and see how it goes if they think it would be beneficial.

content.content: What I find interesting are the recent delegates that are already made up of a group of people who work at studying and understanding the inner workings and daily changes of MKR.  This mitigates the concern that delegates don’t have enough time or that they cannot be an expert in every area.  If delegate compensation were to increase, I would anticipate more of these groups popping up to outcompete one-person delegates in knowledge and prolific production of ideas and thought.  Clearly delegate compensation is already enough to incentivize some of these groups.  I don’t think it’s necessary to explicitly promote this type of delegate though.  MKR holders may value certain people who provide special insight but would not be willing to work on a team and split compensation.  It’s all a competition and the cream should rise to the top.  What you need right now is probably more visibility and interest.  That doesn’t necessarily only come from increased compensation. Anyhow, in our current environment, I would be very wary of any kind of increase in spending that isn’t strictly necessary.
